page.title: 10Twyning meadow
page.content: Twyning meadow and the adjoining Summer Leasow lie beside the Avon. Together they cover 260 acres and form one of the largest meadows in the country. In the past many people had rights there but now only eight own the freehold meadow, presided over by a head hay warden. Each has his own patch of mowing grass and from the 12th August is allowed to graze first cattle, then sheep. Most of these pasture holders have rights to graze neighbouring rough commons. Brockeridge (188 acres), Showborough and Hill End (22 acres)) and Lord Leys (37 acres). Only Brockeridge is fenced and a small number of cattle and sheep graze it. The principal occupants of Showborough are long staying gypsies who have 15 caravans, allthough a few sheep are there. Five cottagers have common rights but keep no stock there.
